channel.title: Linux - Limit Problem?
channel.description: How do some of you linux users not find it incompetently irritating not being able to use alot of the internets features - such as multiple games in steam not supporting linux? I really want to fully convert to linux but I'm afraid I'm gonna get so aggravated over the limitations it seems to have. An example of this is me not being able to download java. Anyone have any help/suggestions for me? I am currently trying to use the Ubuntu 12.04 platform, are there any better linux platforms that you would recommend?

item.title: Linux - Limit Problem?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

These aren’t limitations within Linux. Linux is technically capable of handling all these things.

Read full topic

item.title: Linux - Limit Problem?
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

[quote=“chillwitm888, post:7, topic:478893”][quote author=Kodiak link=topic=597111.msg4204704#msg4204704 date=1358733989]

For Java, you can go into the Ubuntu software center and type in “Java” and download the Openjdk Runtime and the Icedtea Java Web Start.

Or use the command:

sudo apt-get install openjdk-7-jre icedtea-netx-common

As for the games, there are a lot of games that are only for Windows. Linux gaming is getting much better, but large game developers have pretty much overlooked Linux. Valve is releasing their own console though, called the “SteamBox” and it is based off of Linux. So hopefully sometime in the future, all the games created for the Steambox will unintentionally be compatible with Linux, or at least be easy to port over.

omg i <3 valve im getting the steambox so i can play tf2 on linux
[/quote]
its called Piston or pisten[/quote]

Piston and Steambox are different things.

en.wikipedia.org

Steam (software)

Steam is a digital distribution platform developed by Valve Corporation, which offers digital rights management (DRM), multiplayer gaming, video streaming and social networking services. Steam provides the user with installation and automatic updating of games, and community features such as friends lists and groups, cloud saving, and in-game voice and chat functionality. The software provides a freely available application programming interface (API) called Steamworks, which developers can use t...

Read full topic
